data.title: [Documentation] RichTextLabel newline function does exist
data.body:
**Issue description:**
Tried to call the function `new_line` on a RichTextLabel node and got an exception

```
Invalid call. Nonexistent function 'new_line' in base 'RichTextLabel'.
```

Accordingly to [the documentation](http://docs.godotengine.org/en/stable/classes/class_richtextlabel.html#class-richtextlabel-newline) this function should exists.


**Steps to reproduce:**
* Create a **new scene**
* Add a **RichTextLabel** node
* Attach a script and in the function **ready** put this

```python
extends RichTextLabel

func _ready():
  new_line()
```

data.title: build issues with scons 3.0.0
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Arch Linux, Godot 3 master 


**Issue description:**
I know this is probably not going to become an issue for most of you soon, but just to give you a little heads-up: Godot currently fails to build with scons 3.0, which just hit ArchLinux' [testing] repo. I don't know how far off scons 3 is for other distros, but maybe there's a version independant fix for this ahead of time. This is the error I'm getting:

```
[Initial build] make_authors_header(["editor/authors.gen.h"], ["AUTHORS.md"])
scons: *** [editor/authors.gen.h] NameError : name 'unicode' is not defined
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/SCons/Action.py", line 1197, in execute
    result = self.execfunction(target=target, source=rsources, env=env)
  File "/var/aur/godot-git/src/godot/editor/SCsub", line 183, in make_authors_header
    current_section = escape_string(sections_id[i])
  File "/var/aur/godot-git/src/godot/editor/SCsub", line 10, in escape_string
    if isinstance(s, unicode):
NameError: name 'unicode' is not defined
scons: building terminated because of errors.
```

**Steps to reproduce:**

try to build godot 3 with scons 3.0

data.title: Fix crash when a custom theme can't be loaded

data.title: Add GridMap::get_used_cells. Fixes #11857.
data.body: Should fix #11857 .

data.title: GridMap enhancement - Add a get_used_cells() method like in TileMap
data.body: As in the title, please add a method that returns an array of all filled cells in a GridMap. This method is available on TileMap, and would offer the exact same functionality for GridMap. Example `get_used_cells()`, it would return a simple array of Vector3 positions in grid cell coordinate space.

data.title: GridMap enhancement - Convert an arbitrary point in world space, to GridMap cell coordinates
data.body:
Add a method to GridMap that would convert an arbitrary point to a grid cell coordinate. This is relatively simple to do in GDScript, but it would be a good addition to the base GridMap class.

something like `get_cell_at(Vector3)`

the basic logic for this method would be:
```
var translated_pos = provided_pos / grid_map.get_cell_size()  # convert to cell space
var rounded_pos = Vector3(round(translated_pos.x), round(translated_pos.y), round(translated_pos.z)) # flatten to nearest discrete cell  
return rounded_pos
```
This might need adjustments for coordinates in negative portions along the x, y or z axes, I'm not sure.

data.title: GridMap enhancement - A signal or callback for on_cell_changed()
data.body:
The GridMap node would be an order of magnitude more powerful if I could have an editor script be able to detect whenever a cell has changed.

This could be achieved by any of a number of options. I'm not sure which would be the most appropriate method:

- A notification that i could check for in _notification()
- A signal (not sure if having signals that fire in editor/tool mode would be appropriate?)
- A method that could be overridden in a tool mode script that extends GridMap, maybe _on_cell_changed(cell_pos)

With this simple addition, I could write an auto-tile editor script in GDScript that I could share with everyone. You could have variation in tiles occur automatically; ie, place a tree tile and have a random one of six tree models spawn. You could have tiles automatically rotate in specific ways.

There would be lots of possibilities opened up by this.

Visual Scripting: Editor crash on clicking `path` port in `get_node()`
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Windows 10, Godot 3 built on commit 454dec2f2

**Issue description:**
Clicking on the text box next to `path` port in `NodePath` node with function `get_node` crash the editor.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3048558/31215482-dc997976-a9d9-11e7-8e6f-21e09ac867ed.png)

**Steps to reproduce:**
Drag a node from scene tree into the editor,
Select `get_node`
Click on the text box next to `path` port.

data.title: Visual Scripting: "Invalid returns count" error on `CallInstance`
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Windows 10, Godot 3 built on commit 454dec2f2

**Issue description:**
`Call` node on `Instance` mode throws this error on some functions:

```
Invalid returns count for call_mode == CALL_MODE_INSTANCE
```

This doesn't happen with `Node` mode on `Call` node

**Steps to reproduce:**
Drag in a reference of `Node`
Instance a reference of another `Node`
Drag in a `Call` node
Set `Call Mode` to `Instance`
Set `Base Type` to `Node`
Set `Function` to `add_child`
Plug the first `Node` into `instance` port
Plug the second `Node` into `node` port
Run

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3048558/31213937-33c9835a-a9d3-11e7-8244-acec3d47a671.png)

data.title: Ambient light refresh issue when adding a new procedural sky
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Win10 current build of Godot3

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
When you add a new environment node and add a new procedural sky, there is initially no ambient light from the sky (image1):

![sky1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7741669/31212880-f1a7e1e4-a9ee-11e7-947f-b8e5aaf70067.jpg)

If any of the ambient light parameters are fiddled with, the sky ambient comes back on(image2). Note that image2 has the same ambient sky settings as image 1. Seems to be a refresh issue. @reduz I noticed this issue directly after you added the color + sky option, so likely related.

![sky2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7741669/31212940-6526ef5c-a9ef-11e7-8d60-7ead3bf113c2.jpg)





**Steps to reproduce:**
- add new environment node
- add new procedural sky...note no ambient light
- change ambient light energy from 1 to 1 and see ambient light pop back on 

**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->

data.title: Mono: support exported parent class fields
data.body:
This exposes exported parent class fields in the inspector.  It behaves like C# overriding / hiding.  If the child class has a field with the same name as one of its ancestors, we use the child's field.

@neikeq: I have no clue if this is the right approach.  Let me know if I did something wrong ðŸ˜„

data.title: 2 shadow map issues
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Win10 current build of Godot3


**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->

Issue 1: When a scene with a shadow mapped spotlight is run, it sometimes exhibits artifacts. The image on the left shows a sample scene when run the first time. There is a cutout part of the shadow directly under the sphere. If the scene is reloaded using get_tree().reload_current_scene() it then looks correct as can be seen on the right. 

![shadow_map_bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7741669/31212266-4b1b9f12-a9eb-11e7-9691-9ab2a79bd238.jpg)

Similarly, when the test scene is first loaded, the shadow artifact can be seen under the sphere, but if the spotlight is toggled off and on, it looks correct(as is illustrated in the second image)

![shadow_map_bug2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7741669/31212528-ca0493fa-a9ec-11e7-8373-9b18b2c7505b.jpg)


Issue 2: When a scene is reloaded using get_tree().reload_current_scene() and has a shadow mapped spotlight or omni, the console gets spammed with an opengl error message stating:

ERROR: _shadow_atlas_find_shadow: Condition ' !sli ' is true. Continuing..:
   At: drivers/gles3/rasterizer_scene_gles3.cpp:270
ERROR: getornull: Condition ' !id_map.has(p_rid.get_data()) ' is true. returned: __null
   At: core/rid.h:164

This will happen with any scene containing either an omni or spotlight with shadow enabled. The error only ever happens upon reload and slows down the game severely!

**Steps to reproduce:**
- run the following test scene and hit spacebar to reload the scene. This scene will demonstrate the 2 bugs described.

**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->

[shadow_map_bug.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1358154/shadow_map_bug.zip)

data.title: Fixed uninitialized local and improved msbuild search and usability
data.body:
- Fixed uninitialized local.
- When attaching a script to an object, we add it to the C# project if it's not already in (Noticed a few issues on domain unload after this, running the GC before finalizing the domain fixed them).
- Search msbuild in a few other locations other than PATH on Unix. Notably: `/Library/Frameworks/Mono.framework/Versions/Current/bin/` on OSX.

data.title: Mono missing ProjectSettings.Get
data.body:
For instance, there's no way to get the project's name (or any other setting) as you can in GDScript.

C#:

    string projectName = ProjectSettings.Get("application/config/name"); // Doesn't exist in C#

GDScript:

    var project_name = ProjectSettings.get("application/config/name") # Exists in GDScript

Thanks!

data.title: Fix Python 3 build
data.body:
- Take care of the differences in handling unicode characters in `escape_string` (formerly in `editor/SCsub`, now in `compat.py)`.
- Conditionally include `_winreg` or `winreg` in the Mono editor module.

I've removed the `encoding` argument from `escape_string` since it does not really make sense. (It's value is used internally to convert a Unicode string into bytes. The Python 2 version uses the `ascii` encoding, but that can't be used on Python 3 since AFAICT there is no error mode that produces the desired behavior. Therefore on Python 3 I'm encoding using UTF-8 and manually converting non-ascii code points to C escapes. But neither version will do anything sensible if called with an `encoding` argument that doesn't match its default.)

In Python 3 the manual conversion to C escapes could be avoided by using Unicode escapes in the generated C++-Files, but that would require C++11 support and is therefore probably not a feasible solution.

data.title: Screen space reflections behaving strangely when used with an orthographic Camera
data.body:
Currently using a Windows build of Godot 3.0 from a few days ago.

**Issue description:**
When using an orthographic camera in combination with screen space reflections, the reflections act differently to what can be expected when using the editor in orthographic mode. Using a simple scene with a plane and a cube with reflective materials:

![godot3ortho](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3076277/31198275-88b03f18-a94b-11e7-9999-a13bb03a5204.png)

Perspective mode on the other hand, looks exactly the same in editor vs the camera.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Create any scene with reflective materials.
Add a camera and set it to orthographic mode
view scene in editor (in orthographic mode), compare it to camera preview or build.

Not sure if this is an actual issue, or something simple that I'm missing. If it is the latter then I apologize.

data.title: Updated ios x86 simulator build to match target version of real devices.

data.title: Fix "enable_object_picking" disables editor tooltips
data.body: "enable_object_picking" was linked to Viewport's set_fixed_process() and controlled processing of NOTIFICATION_FIXED_PROCESS which handles physics_object_picking, tooltips and debug drawing collision contacts. Fixes #8347

data.title: No GUI error message when trying to export 64 bit executable with no 64 bit templates available
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Windows 7 64bit, Godot ef08228 (tools.32)

**Issue description:**
When only 32 bit templates were built and installed, in the exports settings (Project -> Export) 64 bit build is still available and is the default option. After pressing 'Export Project' and choosing the name, the dialog is silently closed. The only clue is in the terminal:

```
test user file: C:\Users\abyss\AppData\Roaming/Godot/templates/3.0-alpha/windows
_64_debug.exe
test system file: 3.0-alpha/windows_64_debug.exe
ERROR: DirAccess::copy: Condition ' err ' is true. returned: err
   At: core\os\dir_access.cpp:303
ERROR: ProjectExportDialog::_export_project_to_path: Failed to export project
   At: editor\project_export.cpp:737
```

**Steps to reproduce:**
- Build 32 bit templates, but not 64 bit ones, move them to C:\Users\ USERNAME \AppData\Roaming\Godot\templates\3.0-alpha
- Open Godot editor
- Create an empty project
- Try to export the project as executable

**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Windows 7 64bit, Godot ef08228 (tools.32)

**Issue description:**
By default, when I'm creating a project, I see this:
![default](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11571820/31186125-79395ad4-a936-11e7-800d-3279056cf010.png)

The default path is on C:\ drive, but the drive selected is D: (Godot executable is on D:\).
If I want to browse D:\ then, I need to first select C: in the right drop-down menu, and then D: again

**Steps to reproduce:**
Start Godot, choose "New Project"

data.title: Opening a folder with .cs files crashes Godot (Mono related?)
data.body:
Godot 3.0 git HEAD 64 bit

Manjaro Linux 64 bit
Ubuntu 17.10b2
Windows 10


**Issue description:**

When navigating into a CSharp scripts folder Godot crashes if there's a .mono folder and if there are no icons of the scripts in the ~/.godot/tmp folder.

@neikeq I believe this is Mono related as a lot of Mono items are in the crash log, deleting the .mono folder fixes the crash, or if I simply rename files from having .cs to .gd (and leave the .mono folder there) it no longer crashes.

**Steps to reproduce:**

edit: Okay, I've narrowed it down a bit more. I tried it on Ubuntu 17.10b2 and I was able to navigate to the folder as long as I didn't first make a build.

I was then able to cause it to break again by:

1) Deleting the ~/.godot/tmp folder
2) Make a build (F5/F6)
3) Restart the editor
4) Navigate to the Scripts folder
Crash

I was able to navigate again to the folder by:

1) Deleting the .mono folder for the project
2) Restart the editor
3) Navigate to the folder
No crash

So, it seems somehow related to failing to generate icons when there's a successful build in the .mono folder?

I've made a video: [DirectoryOpenCrash.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1356420/DirectoryOpenCrash.zip)


**Link to minimal example project:**

edit: Here's a simple project:

[Test_Proj_CS.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1357254/Test_Proj_CS.zip)

edit: Removed the crash dump as you should now be able to get your own now that the bug is reproducible.

data.title: Unpredictable Behavior of MeshInstance's Generated CollisionShape
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Antergos x86_64 / Godot master ef08228

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
Situation:
- A Spatial root
    - StaticBody with MeshInstance with CubeMesh
        - CollisionShape
            A. Manually created with BoxShape 
            B. Generated by 'Create Trimesh Collision Sibling'
            C. Generated by 'Create Convex Collision Sibling'
    - RigidBody with MeshInstance with SphereMesh, positioned above the StaticBody and tilted
        - CollisionShape
            A. Manually created with SphereShape 
            B. Generated by 'Create Trimesh Collision Sibling'
            C. Generated by 'Create Convex Collision Sibling'

Expected: all collide without a drop in framerate
Happened:

Sphere\\Box|A|B|C
-|-|-|-
A|Collide as expected|Collide with expected inaccuracy|Collide as expected
B|Collide with expected inaccuracy|**No collision**|A drop in framerate for split second but collide with expected inaccuracy 
C|Framerate drop to 1\*|Framerate drop to 1\*|Framerate drop to 1\*

\* Somewhat understandable due to high number of vertices, but why is this not the case with concave shape?

**Link to minimal example project:**
[collisionshape.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1356135/collisionshape.zip)
